hints_html:
For each of the three equilibrium points, calculate the eigenvalues of the corresponding Jacobian matrix.

For your plots, find the eigenvectors corresponding to these eigenvalues. Remember that solutions which start on an eigenvector, stay on this eigenvector.
hints_latex:
For each of the three equilibrium points, calculate the eigenvalues of
the corresponding Jacobian matrix.

For your plots, find the eigenvectors corresponding to these
eigenvalues. Remember that solutions which start on an eigenvector, stay
on this eigenvector.
hints_raw:
For each of the three equilibrium points, calculate the eigenvalues of the corresponding Jacobian matrix.
For your plots, find the eigenvectors corresponding to these eigenvalues. Remember that solutions which start on an eigenvector, stay on this eigenvector.
question: 7 (c)
sols_html:
Using the Jacobian from 7 (b) we find the linearization of the system in the critical points.

Critical point \(y_0 = (0,0)\)

\[\begin{aligned} J(0,0) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0\\ 0 & 1\end{pmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

  • This matrix is diagonal and so the diagonal elements are the eigenvalues

  • This matrix is positive definite since its two eigenvalues \(1, 2\) are positive. All positive eigenvalues indicate that the critical point \((0,0)\) is an unstable node.

  • The eigenvector for the eigenvalue \(1\) is \(\begin{pmatrix} 0\\1\end{pmatrix}\).

  • The eigenvector for the eigenvalue \(2\) is \(\begin{pmatrix} 1\\0\end{pmatrix}\).

  • The linearized critical point in the phase space is on the following figure:

Critical point \(y_0 = (2,0)\)

\[\begin{aligned} J(2,0) =\begin{pmatrix} -2 & -2\\ 0 & -1\end{pmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

  • The eigenvalues are \(-2, -1\), because a triangular matrix has its eigenvalues on the diagonal. The eigenvalues are both negative and hence, the matrix is negative definite and this critical point is a stable node.

  • The eigenvector for the eigenvalue \(-2\) is \(\begin{pmatrix} 1\\0\end{pmatrix}\) because of the triangular shape of the matrix.

  • For the other eigenvector we need to work a little more and calculate the null space of \(\displaystyle J(2,0) - (-1I)\):

\((J(2,0)+1I)(v_1,v_2)^T = \begin{pmatrix}-1 & -2\\0&0\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}v_1\\ v_2\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}-v_1 - 2v_2\\0\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}\)

Hence, \(v_1 = -2v_2\)

  • We find the the eigenvector for \(-1\) is \(\begin{pmatrix} -2\\1\end{pmatrix}\).

  • The linearized critical point in the phase space is on the following figure:

Critical point \(y_0 = (1,1)\)

\[\begin{aligned} J(1,1) = \begin{pmatrix}-1 & -1\\ -1 & 0\end{pmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

  • For the eigenvalues we calculate

\(det\begin{pmatrix}-1-\lambda & -1\\ -1 & -\lambda\end{pmatrix} = \lambda^2 + \lambda - 1 = 0\)

\(\lambda = \frac{-1\pm\sqrt{5}}{2}\)

  • The eigenvalue for \(\frac{-1-\sqrt5}{2}\) is the null space of

\(\begin{pmatrix} -1+\frac{1+\sqrt5}{2} & -1\\ -1 & \frac{1+\sqrt5}{2}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}v_1\\v_2\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}\)

\(v_1 = \frac{1+\sqrt5}{2} v_2\)

so that the eigenvector is \(\begin{pmatrix}1+\sqrt5\\2\end{pmatrix}\).

  • The eigenvalue for \(\frac{-1+\sqrt5}{2}\) is the null space of

\(\begin{pmatrix} -1+\frac{1-\sqrt5}{2} & -1\\ -1 & \frac{1-\sqrt5}{2}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}v_1\\v_2\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}\)

\(v_1 = \frac{1-\sqrt5}{2} v_2\)

and the eigenvector is \(\begin{pmatrix}1-\sqrt5\\2\end{pmatrix}\).

  • Because one eigenvalue is positive, the other negative, the critical point is not asymptotically stable. Along the eigenvector for \(\frac{-1+\sqrt5}{2}\), the solution moves away from the critical point, along the eigenvector for \(\frac{-1-\sqrt{5}}{2}\), the solution moves towards the critical point. Since the eigenvalues do not have the same sign, the matrix is indefinite and the equilibrium is a saddle point.

  • See the following figure:
sols_raw:
Using the Jacobian from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH215/December_2011/Question_7_(b)|7 (b)]] we find the linearization of the system in the critical points.


'''Critical point <math>\ y_0 = (0,0)</math>'''

:<math> J(0,0) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0\\ 0 & 1\end{pmatrix}. </math>

* This matrix is diagonal and so the diagonal elements are the eigenvalues
* This matrix is ''positive definite'' since its two eigenvalues <math> \ 1, 2 </math> are positive. All positive eigenvalues indicate that the critical point <math>\ (0,0)</math> is an '''unstable node'''.
* The eigenvector for the eigenvalue <math>\ 1</math> is <math>\begin{pmatrix} 0\\1\end{pmatrix}</math>.
* The eigenvector for the eigenvalue <math>\ 2</math> is <math>\begin{pmatrix} 1\\0\end{pmatrix}</math>.
* The linearized critical point in the phase space is on the following figure:

:[[File:Fig 215 2011 7c1.jpg|400px|Phase space for linearization of critical point (0,0)]]


'''Critical point <math>\ y_0 = (2,0)</math>'''

: <math> J(2,0) =\begin{pmatrix} -2 & -2\\ 0 & -1\end{pmatrix}. </math>

* The eigenvalues are <math>\ -2, -1</math>, because a triangular matrix has its eigenvalues on the diagonal.  The eigenvalues are both negative and hence, the matrix is ''negative definite'' and this critical point is a '''stable node'''.
* The eigenvector for the eigenvalue <math>\ -2</math> is <math>\begin{pmatrix} 1\\0\end{pmatrix}</math> because of the triangular shape of the matrix.
* For the other eigenvector we need to work a little more and calculate the null space of <math>\displaystyle J(2,0) - (-1I)</math>:

<math>(J(2,0)+1I)(v_1,v_2)^T = \begin{pmatrix}-1 & -2\\0&0\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}v_1\\ v_2\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}-v_1 - 2v_2\\0\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}</math>

Hence, <math> \ v_1 = -2v_2</math>

* We find the the eigenvector for <math> \ -1</math> is <math>\begin{pmatrix} -2\\1\end{pmatrix}</math>.

* The linearized critical point in the phase space is on the following figure:

[[File:Fig 215 2011 7c2.jpg|400px|Phase space of critical point (2,0)]]


'''Critical point <math>\ y_0 = (1,1)</math>'''

:<math> J(1,1) = \begin{pmatrix}-1 & -1\\ -1  & 0\end{pmatrix}.</math>

* For the eigenvalues we calculate

<math>det\begin{pmatrix}-1-\lambda & -1\\ -1  & -\lambda\end{pmatrix} = \lambda^2 + \lambda - 1 = 0</math>

<math>\lambda = \frac{-1\pm\sqrt{5}}{2}</math>

* The eigenvalue for <math>\frac{-1-\sqrt5}{2}</math> is the null space of

<math> \begin{pmatrix} -1+\frac{1+\sqrt5}{2} & -1\\ -1 & \frac{1+\sqrt5}{2}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}v_1\\v_2\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}</math>

<math> v_1 = \frac{1+\sqrt5}{2} v_2 </math>

so that the eigenvector is <math>\begin{pmatrix}1+\sqrt5\\2\end{pmatrix}</math>. 

* The eigenvalue for <math>\frac{-1+\sqrt5}{2}</math> is the null space of

<math> \begin{pmatrix} -1+\frac{1-\sqrt5}{2} & -1\\ -1 & \frac{1-\sqrt5}{2}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}v_1\\v_2\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}</math>

<math> v_1 = \frac{1-\sqrt5}{2} v_2 </math>

and the eigenvector is <math>\begin{pmatrix}1-\sqrt5\\2\end{pmatrix}</math>.

* Because one eigenvalue is positive, the other negative, the critical point is not asymptotically stable. Along the eigenvector for <math> \frac{-1+\sqrt5}{2}</math>, the solution moves away from the critical point, along the eigenvector for <math>\frac{-1-\sqrt{5}}{2}</math>, the solution moves towards the critical point. Since the eigenvalues do not have the same sign, the matrix is ''indefinite'' and the equilibrium is a '''saddle point'''.

* See the following figure:

:[[File:Fig 215 2011 7c3.jpg|400px|Phase space for linearization of critical point (1,1)]]
statement_html:
Consider the system of equations

\[\begin{aligned} x' &= x(2-x-y) \\ y' &= y(1-x)\end{aligned}\]

(c) Classify each critical (fixed) point, and sketch the phase portrait of the linearized system near each critical point.
statement_latex:
Consider the system of equations

\begin{align*}
x' &= x(2-x-y) \\
y' &= y(1-x)
\end{align*}

\textbf{(c)} Classify each critical (fixed) point, and sketch the phase
portrait of the linearized system near each critical point.
statement_raw:
Consider the system of equations

:<math>
\begin{align}
x' &= x(2-x-y) \\
y' &= y(1-x)
\end{align}
</math>

'''(c)''' Classify each critical (fixed) point, and sketch the phase portrait of the linearized system near each critical point.
